100.description: The initial part of the request has been received, and the client should proceed with the rest of the request.

101.description: The server agrees to switch protocols specified in the Upgrade header field of the request.

102.description: The server has received and is processing the request but has not yet completed the process.

103.description: The server is sending some hints to the client even before the final response is available.

200.description: The request has succeeded, and the requested resource is returned as the response.

201.description: The request has been fulfilled, and a new resource has been created as a result.

202.description: The request has been accepted for processing, but the processing is not complete.

203.description: The server is a transforming proxy that has received the request but has modified the response.

204.description: The server has successfully processed the request, but there is no content to return.

205.description: The server instructs the client to reset the current resource.

206.description: The server has fulfilled the partial GET request for the resource.

207.description: The response status is a collection of independent responses, potentially differing in status.

208.description: The members of a DAV binding have already been enumerated in a preceding part of the (multistatus) response, and are not being included again.

218.description: Used as an Easter egg or joke, indicating that the server is returning a response despite encountering an error or problematic situation.

226.description: The server has fulfilled a request for the resource, and the response is a representation of the result of one or more instance-manipulations applied to the current instance.

300.description: The requested resource has multiple choices, each with its own URI and representation.

301.description: The requested resource has been permanently moved to a new location.

302.description: The requested resource has been temporarily moved to a different location.

303.description: The response to the request can be found at a different URI.

304.description: The client can use a cached version of the response.

307.description: The requested resource is temporarily located at a different URI.

308.description: The requested resource has been permanently moved to a different URI.

400.description: The server cannot process the request due to client error.

403.description: The server understands the request but refuses to fulfill it.

404.description: The requested resource could not be found on the server.

405.description: The requested method is not allowed for the resource.

406.description: The server cannot produce a response matching the client's requested characteristics.

407.description: The client must authenticate itself to a proxy server.

408.description: The server timed out waiting for the request from the client.

409.description: The request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the target resource.

410.description: The requested resource is no longer available and has been permanently removed.

411.description: The server requires a Content-Length header in the request.

412.description: One or more conditions in the request header fields evaluated to false.

413.description: The server refused to process the request because the payload is too large.

414.description: The server refused the request because the URI is too long.

415.description: The server does not support the request's media type.

416.description: The requested range is not satisfiable.

417.description: The server cannot meet the requirements specified by the Expect request header.

418.description: This code was defined in 1998 as one of the traditional IETF April Fools' jokes, in RFC 2324, Hyper Text Coffee Pot Control Protocol, and is not expected to be implemented by actual HTTP servers. However, known implementations do exist.

419.description: Similar to 401 Unauthorized, but indicates that the client's session has expired and needs to reauthenticate.

420.description: A non-standard status code typically used to indicate that a method failed on the server.

422.description: The server understands the content of the request but cannot process it due to semantic errors or business logic failures.

423.description: The requested resource is locked and cannot be accessed until a specified condition is met.

424.description: The request failed due to the failure of a previous request.

428.description: The server requires the request to be conditional, typically requiring the inclusion of a specific header field.

429.description: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time, exceeding the server's rate limit.

431.description: The server refuses to process the request because the request headers are too large.

451.description: The server is denying access to the resource due to legal reasons, such as censorship or government-mandated restrictions.

500.description: A generic server error has occurred.

501.description: The server does not support the functionality required to fulfill the request.

502.description: The server, while acting as a gateway or proxy, received an invalid response from an upstream server.

503.description: The server is currently unable to handle the request due to temporary overloading or maintenance.

504.description: The server, while acting as a gateway or proxy, did not receive a timely response from the upstream server.

505.description: The server does not support the HTTP protocol version used in the request.

506.description: The server has an internal configuration error: the chosen variant resource is configured to engage in transparent content negotiation itself and is therefore not a proper end point in the negotiation process.

507.description: The server is unable to store the representation needed to complete the request.

508.description: The server detected an infinite loop while processing the request.

510.description: The policy for accessing the requested resource requires further extensions to be made by the client.

511.description: The client needs to authenticate to gain network access.
